segments.text: What we were talking yesterday about, really about concepts of the environment, and I wanted to open up today by asking how you react to people like Jacques Cousteau, for example, who talk about oceans dying.
Well, I don't take them too seriously except the impact they have on this.

community and congress and so on that their voices is rather loud out of proportion probably to the amount of information they have available these environmental questions are certainly very complicated and and many of them were i think we have only very fragmentary information about
And it's going to take a long time to actually solve them.
It's probably some merit in drawing attention to the problems in general through advocates such as Cousteau, who speak out very loudly on them.
But I think that they probably create more problems than they resolve.
Well, how would you call attention, let's say, to the average American concerning problems of science in the environment?
Oh, this is even more complicated.
An aspect of it that interests me is really, I think, the semantic question.
And it involves...

at least two aspects and one is just the general question of vocabulary of not understanding each other's words but the more fundamental one is how you can draw people's attention to and inform them about features of the art environment which have not
in their experience or education being recognized as significant features that this is a problem that I'm confronted with right now in the Institute for Marine Studies of trying to

describe certain characteristics of the ocean and the processes that affect the ocean in terms that will be meaningful to lawyers and other people whose educational experience has been in the social sciences.
Now, when these people come to your institute, the first thing you do, do you spend time describing the ocean and the ocean's viability?

Well, one of the first courses they take is one which I teach, which I call the ocean system, which is essentially a comprehensive course in terms of subject matter, but obviously not a very profound one about the characteristics of the ocean
atmosphere and other of the environmental components that make up what I call the ocean system.
And so it's primarily just a direct task of trying to provide some understanding with the constraint that they have very little scientific background, most of these people.
And it's also a problem of essentially getting and holding their interest in matters which in many cases must seem to them as trivial and insignificant and unimportant.
And this is the kind of problem that intrigues me very much here as to how one can gain the necessary rapport to be able to
communicate adequately with these people without the great depth of scientific understanding.
And so, primarily then, the Marine Institute, what you're trying to do is appoint the layman then, I suppose.
Well, we don't go very far into educating the public here.
We're concerned with
with the education of a relatively small number of what we hope will be sort of experts later on.
And yet the same sort of problem, I think, is common to almost any audience outside of the scientific community.
And even within science, you have the same sort of communications problems these days.
The point I'm trying to emphasize to you, it's not just a matter of vocabulary, although this is a fairly large component.
It's even conceptual.
One of the sort of an example of this was that there are, of course, many so-called laws in science.
And it dawned on me one day that to a lawyer, the term law certainly has a different meaning than the way it is used.
Science, oh.
Go ahead.
Now, when they're through with the institute,
or when they finish what amounts to their curriculum in the institute, then do you expect them to go to work for the government or simply be more aware of environmental problems?
We've entered this topic by the back door here.
The institute was set up about five years ago by the university as a graduate activity to offer graduate courses and conduct research.
what we now call an area of marine affairs.

And what we're striving to do is to draw together the information and techniques and understanding from a variety of different fields and give the students an opportunity to get a kind of breadth of understanding of what these problems are.

these three there are in general sort of three general areas of disciplines that are involved one being the natural sciences or the environmental scientists the other two are involved the social sciences economics law political science
anthropology, hopefully some history, and then the technological sciences or engineering sciences that concern with how you do, how you carry out various kinds of operations.
And these are obviously focused on the ocean, so they're sort of the marine technologies.
So we're working on a very broad sort of base.
At the moment, we're concentrating on a two-year master's program.
And during that time, the principal sort of effort will be to provide students with a sort of breadth in these various fields.
And I mentioned the one course that I teach.
I also offer a second one, which has more
concern with how you apply the environmental information to a variety of different sort of problems that affect human activities.
I don't deal with the economic or legal or political issues, although I have to keep these things in mind, otherwise we wouldn't be meeting our goal of trying to develop an interdisciplinary program.
Aside from the textbook, which everybody concedes is a major contribution to oceanography, what would you name as your other most important contribution?
I realize that's a terrible question to ask you, but nevertheless.
Well, I agree with you.
I think it's a terrible one.
I think that probably the development of the undergraduate program here at the University of Washington, and I

I select that rather than the graduate program, which is obviously closely coupled to it, because there have been a number of opportunities for graduate study in this country, although we were the pioneers, really, in the undergraduate program.
There are a couple of other things that I will be inclined to bring up that I am rather proud of,
One of them was that I broke the color line in the hydrographic office.
Well, I was there up until that time.
The blacks, particularly, had never been hired except for very low-level jobs.
And I started implying black professionals.
And after that, why, the doors were open.
The other star I had in my crown, maybe rather tarnished,

is that I essentially opened up the opportunities for women in oceanography because I employed girls, ladies, both during the war and in Washington, and more particularly I made it possible for them to go to sea, which was one of the more difficult obstacles to overcome 20, 30 years ago when there was a
very strong prejudice against having females on board ship.
So I think I contributed my small part, at least towards the liberation of the females.
There has always been a charge leveled at the sciences, rightly or wrongly, that scientists or the discipline of science itself has had the greatest amount of prejudice towards women.
Would you agree with that?
I don't think it's been particularly noticeable as a prejudice against women.
There's certainly been the feeling that in many cases they were physically incapable of going to sea because of the strenuous nature of the
work that had to be carried on, but that is certainly no longer the case.
The other concern in years gone by, which I shared in some degree, was the fact that I thought it was probably in many cases in a sense a poor investment to spend time and effort in educating
girls in science and then have them get married and leave the field.
It just wasn't, in a sense, very cost effective in a way.
But I think the opportunities have existed for a long time.
I'm surprised that more haven't, in a way, gone into the field than I see.
Many of them are apparently attracted by it, but are unable to continue through to, well, let's say, a PhD level.
They get discouraged or get distracted and tend to leave earlier than that.
But I have a feeling that a lot of,
females would like to be associated with science rather than actually be scientists, but this is hard to offer any sort of evidence on this.

One thing that doesn't interest me very much is the fact that we're getting quite a few females in the Institute for Marine Studies program, which sort of surprised me because I hadn't anticipated this.

And it may be that this sort of interdisciplinary policy management type problems is something to which they're singularly endowed and maybe are better at it than the men who may prefer to specialize.
But this is purely my own speculation.
I don't know if there's any basis for it at all.
I think even the domestic chores that most women undertake
a very complicated set of policy and management problem.
And maybe they're better able to cope with all these interacting type things that go towards the household than a man is.
Now, the next series of questions I have to ask really concerns sort of the future of oceanography.
First of all, is that there have
have been sort of in fields in oceanography, if I may use that word.
That, for example, nuclear engineering was a big field in oceanography in the late 50s and early 60s.
What sort of do you see now as the future of oceanography, the in fields?
What would you tell a young oceanographer to do beside his interest?
Well, I think we went through a period
that probably fifteen, maybe twenty years began in the late fifties when there was a good deal of popular interest in the ocean.

not only as being a sort of adventurous region, the last frontier, and similar sort of analogies were drawn, but that a lot of young people had the idea that this was an environment in which there was a lot of opportunity to make money.
And I think now this attitude is changing.
But it certainly attracted a great many
the young people in that period.
As far as the future is concerned, it's inevitable that the world will depend to an increasing amount upon the resources of the ocean and upon the use of the ocean for
purposes that are related but not directly dependent on marine resources.
Transportation is an example of this.
And I think there's a great deal of opportunity in essentially innovative types of engineering and the development of possibly entirely new kinds of

of engineering enterprises that, and these are always hard to really identify, and there's the whole question of food from the sea, which is a very, very important one, and so that anything that we can learn which will contribute to essentially a high level of
of production in the ocean and more effective means of utilizing these food resources.
There are many, many examples that could be cited, but I see no sort of one or two kind of unique developments.
As we were talking earlier, if the manganese nodule mining venture goes, this opens, I believe, a whole array of possibilities of other types of materials that might be taken from the deep sea.
I have nothing specific in mind here, but just the existence of a technology may suggest other
since the applications of that kind of a technology.

There's undoubtedly going to be further developments in the search for petroleum materials beneath the sea, and presumably this is also going to go into deeper and deeper water as a technology develops.
But probably of almost equal importance these days are the questions that
that arise from the environmental concern or the preservation of the ocean as well as possible in the face of ever increasing impacts of human activities on the environment.
And in this sense, it's just part and parcel of the total global environment as I see it.
I noticed you didn't mention, for example, physical oceanography or systematics.
Well, all right.
This is, as I said, there are many different examples.
One of the things that we're probably going to see are efforts to try and obtain energy from the ocean.
And we have a few sort of scattered
relatively small examples of this, of the use of tidal energy.
There are plans now to try and develop the thermal energy to make use of the heat that's present in the water, possibly to use ocean currents to drive large propeller-like
devices, the equivalent of windmills.
And there's the possibility that we may want to use the certain areas of the ocean.
Probably they would be near the coast for the direct capture of solar energy in some scheme analogous to those used on land.
So there are certainly a lot of physical
questions or aspects of the physical characteristics of the ocean that are going to be important.
But most of these things are going to take, I think, a very long time to see any great development.
Do you see more and more use of technology in oceanography?
Oh, I think this is what has hampered the field in many ways.

There has been a revolution in technologies that has occurred really as a consequence of the developments in the whole field of electronics, new kinds of instruments and sensing devices that have come along.
But these are primarily in sort of chemical, physical, and in part in the
geophysical area.

And what always seems to me to be lacking is the very slow developments of instrumentation and techniques in the biological field, where in many cases we're using methods that are roughly 100 years old.
And I'm always expecting to see some major sort of developments in the biological aspect, but so far haven't seen a great deal.
What about the use of the computer, though, in biology and predicting all kinds of ecosystems?
A lot of computer work is being done in effect to build many oceans.
Well, there's a lot of work going on in modeling.
The computers certainly encourage developments of this kind, but the problem is at the present time... Do you want me to go ahead?
Sure.

All right, the difficulty with the development of models and the use of computers as a mechanism for essentially handling the numerical aspects of these is that there are still major gaps in basic knowledge concerning the ocean.
So most of the models that I've seen suffer from being too restricted or too hypothetical.
They're not very close approximation to the real ocean.
One of your contemporaries has suggested that the problem with computer work is that they're not out in the ocean enough to know what the ocean works like.
Would you agree with that?
Well, this may be so.
There have been some

sort of interesting developments in computers, and some computers do go to sea, and not the very large ones, but it is possible now to process data in essentially real time, so it's available very quickly.

And there have been some efforts made to actually predict on essentially a day-to-day business, I'm sorry, day-to-day basis, and then, in effect, test what the validity of the projections is being made by the computers.
I think they serve a useful purpose, any of these attempts at modeling.
even though they may not solve a problem, they usually tend to sharpen up the questions and indicate serious deficiencies in the type of information.
What I'm concerned with here is the fact that there are very few types of measurements that are made or can be made today which essentially give rates at which various things are occurring.
And

I am not sure that we're going to be able to arrive at many of these, and this is one of the main difficulties with any of these sort of modeling techniques, the lack of understanding of the processes and the rates at which they occur.
Now, I want to change the title for a reason.
